Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Italian grammar, specifically many different types of tenses
This course built on material learned in Italian 110. It's more grammar-intensive. I learned a lot of vocabulary and verb tenses including future, conditional, and subjunctive tenses.

I learned about basic grammatical structures in Italian, such as verb conjugations, and also more about the culture and history of Italy by watching Italian films, reading Italian literature, and listening to Italian songs.
Developed wonderful skills at speaking, comprehending, and writing in Italian.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Costanza was a great instructor. While I liked starting class with a new song, I would've like the songs to take up less time. I think doing some more grammar/vocabulary practice in breakout rooms would've been helpful.

Strengths: the seminar format is conducive to engaging with fellow classmates and practicing listening/speaking skills, the course is highly organized, the textbook is very thorough, Costanza is extremely nice and welcoming Weaknesses: some of the asynchronous assignments would take a little long to complete (but they were pretty infrequent and still enjoyable!)

The strengths of this course are the amount of material covered and the immersion experience that results from having the class every day of the week. One weakness is that the course is designed to prioritize "quantity over quality" (at times there was so much material covered in such a short amount of time that retention became difficult later on in the course).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the class. I think it would've been more interesting in-person. Some days felt long when we were all in the main room the whole time.
Succeeded: breakout rooms to practice Italian! Could be improved: screen sharing at times could be a bit slow and clunky, but this was mostly due to Zoom

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student, especially with Costanza. She is an amazing professor.

Yes! Costanza is an amazing professor who genuinely cares about her students and wants to get to know them. She made class exciting and engaging every day. I always looked forward to her class and the welcoming environment she fostered. This class quickly became my Zoom family.
Yes! Italian is fun and the instructors are nice. The daily workload is not very much.

I'd recommend Italian at Yale to students who are looking for a fun, low-stress way to fulfill the language requirement! Costanza creates a very easygoing, laidback class environment which makes learning Italian enjoyable. The courseload also is very manageable -- you'll just have to read 1-2 pages in the textbook every day and complete a few exercises. Costanza also makes an effort to introduce students to Italian culture by having students present Italian songs, assigning Italian movies to watch, and reading Italian literature in class.
Yes. You get to learn the greatest language there is.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Zoom meetings every day; some breakout rooms
